author: By Katrina Miller and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Ban on D.E.I. Language Sweeps Through the Sciences
description: President Trump’s executive order is altering scientific exploration across a broad swath of fields, even beyond government agencies, researchers say.
content: The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine is an independent, 162-year-old nongovernmental agency tasked with investigating and reporting on a wide range of subjects. In recent years, diversity, equity and inclusion — collectively known as D.E.I. — have been central to its agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: Large Earthquake Strikes Caribbean Near Cayman Islands
description: The 7.6-magnitude tremor struck south of the Cayman Islands on Saturday. A tsunami warning across much of the Caribbean was lifted.
content: A large, 7.6-magnitude earthquake struck the Caribbean on Saturday evening, prompting a tsunami warning across much of the region, including Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Honduras and Cuba. The warning was later lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rutherford Chang, Who Turned Collections Into Art, Dies at 45
description: He was best known for amassing more than 3,400 copies of the Beatles’ “White Album” and using them to demonstrate the aging of a cultural artifact.
content: Rutherford Chang, a conceptual artist who turned his collection of the Beatles’ “White Album” into a meditation on the aging of a vinyl classic — and who, in another project, melted down 10,000 pennies into a copper block to make a statement about the value of each red cent — died on Jan. 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 45.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Three Men Convicted of Playing a Role in Ring That Preyed on U.S. Museums
description: A jury found them guilty of conspiring as part of a crew to steal art, sports memorabilia and artifacts from smaller museums.
content: For two decades, a crew from Lackawanna County in Pennsylvania traveled to a dozen small museums across the country, where its ringleader smashed through security systems to strip them of art and precious memorabilia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: What Is the Best Way to See the Violence in the Middle East?
description: In “The World After Gaza,” Pankaj Mishra looks for moral clarity in the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.
content: Growing up in a Hindu nationalist household in India in the 1970s, the critic and author Pankaj Mishra felt great admiration for Israel, even as India’s leaders championed the Palestinian cause. Encouraged by his grandfather, an ardent nationalist, he absorbed stories of Israel’s quest for statehood, respecting the determination of the Zionist movement to overcome formidable odds to create a state for the Jews, one that would grant them both safe harbor in a hostile world and an army with the unflinching will to strike its enemies. He even hung a photo of Moshe Dayan, Israel’s eye-patch-wearing defense minister during the 1967 Six-Day War, in his bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: The Most Memorable Looks From the Super Bowl Tunnel Walk
description: From Travis Kelce’s Ron Burgundy-like suit to Saquon Barkley’s Canadian tuxedo, players from both teams embraced the fact that all eyes would be on them.
content: If the Super Bowl is the N.F.L.’s biggest stage, the Super Bowl tunnel is its biggest catwalk. And on Sunday, the Philadelphia Eagles and the Kansas City Chiefs dressed for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: But how much does breed shape a dog’s health and behavior?
description: Here’s what scientists have learned about how a dog’s breed affects its health and behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Cyberattack Disrupts Publication of Lee Newspapers Across the U.S.
description: The media company Lee Enterprises said a “cybersecurity event” had created havoc at dozens of its newspapers, prompting some to publish shorter editions or not print at all.
content: Newspapers across the country owned by the news media company Lee Enterprises were unable to print, had problems with their websites and published smaller issues after a cyberattack last week, the company said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Stacy Cowley
title: Federal Financial Watchdog Ordered to Cease Activity
description: In an email to staff of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the agency’s acting director ordered workers to cease “all supervision and examination activity.”
content: Employees of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau were instructed to cease “all supervision and examination activity” and “all stakeholder engagement,” effectively stopping the agency’s operations, in an email from the director of the Office of Management and Budget, Russell Vought, on Saturday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Rabasca Roepe
title: Love and Money: Why Sharing Accounts Is Good for Your Relationship
description: Fewer couples are combining their bank accounts. But that trend may not promote partners’ overall financial health, experts say.
content: When Nia Darville Stokes-Hicks and Armondi Stokes-Hicks married two years ago, they set up five bank accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Jeremy Singer-Vine
title: How GoFundMe Became a $250 Million Lifeline After the L.A. Fires
description: Donations on the crowdfunding site to people and fire relief efforts have exceeded those for all natural disasters worldwide last year.
content: As the chief executive of the crowdfunding site GoFundMe, Tim Cadogan is no stranger to disasters. But until the Eaton fire forced him to evacuate his own home in Altadena, Calif., last month, a crisis had never landed on his actual doorstep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono and Hannah Beech
title: Happy Tears as 5 Thai Hostages Return Home From Gaza
description: Thais were, after Israelis, the nationality most affected by Hamas’s Oct. 7, 2023, attack, with nearly 40 farm workers killed and almost as many captured.
content: At Gate 10 of the arrivals hall of the Bangkok airport, Wichayada Saeyang stroked her son’s hair, as if he were a small boy, not a grown man. A few feet away, Pongsak Thanna wrapped his arms around his father and did not let go. His tears dampened his father’s shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Tom Robbins, Whose Comic Novels Drew a Cult Following, Dies at 92
description: He blended pop philosophy and absurdist comedy in best-selling books like “Even Cowgirls Get the Blues” and “Skinny Legs and All.”
content: Tom Robbins, whose cosmically comic novels about gargantuan-thumbed hitchhikers, stoned secret agents and mystic stockbrokers caught hold of millions of readers in the 1970s counterculture, died on Sunday at his home in La Conner, Wash. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Charnas
title: Kendrick Lamar Can’t Save the World. Why Do We Expect Him To?
description: Now that he’s performing at the Super Bowl, it seems like he’s inherited a no-win situation for all the conflicted expectations that await him.
content: Kendrick Lamar headlines the Super Bowl halftime show on Sunday already a champion. Last summer, he vanquished the pop superstar Drake in a volley of vicious verses, an incendiary matchup of wits and word craft, hypocrisy and conjecture. Mr. Lamar won in part by depicting Drake as a tourist in Black culture. But his coup de grâce hit Drake squarely on his own turf: the charts. “Not Like Us” transformed our dance floors into Drake roasts and, last weekend, yielded Mr. Lamar five Grammys, including one for song of the year. (Drake’s latest response to all this? A lawsuit.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz and Seamus Hughes
title: A Quick Guide to the Lawsuits Against the Trump Orders
description: Dozens of suits have been filed that seek to stop some of President Trump’s executive orders. Here’s a brief rundown.
content: The legal war over President Trump’s blizzard of executive actions is intensifying, with new lawsuits and fresh rulings emerging now day and night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Court Ruling Gives Hope for Cleanup in Italy’s ‘Land of Fires’
description: The European Court of Human Rights took Italy to task for not protecting citizens in an area where illegal dumping and burning of toxic waste has long been linked to cancers. Residents say it’s about time.
content: Until a few days ago, Antonietta Moccia, a 61-year-old housewife, had little hope that the Italian authorities would ever tackle the illegal waste disposal that had long plagued her town and others just north of Naples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rhodes
title: This Isn’t the Donald Trump America Elected
description: He is making us a corrupted, brittle superpower.
content: In 1962, not long after President John Kennedy created U.S.A.I.D., the federal agency tasked with administering foreign assistance, he welcomed its first mission directors to the White House. He noted the difficult politics of sustaining foreign assistance but called it essential to America’s role as leader of the free world. “There will not be farewell parades to you as you leave,” he said of their imminent deployments, “or parades when you come back.” The reward was the work itself and the larger cause of freedom it served.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Trump and the N.F.L.: A Fraught Relationship Stretching Back Decades
description: The president’s attendance at Sunday’s Super Bowl highlights how his connection to the league has veered from aspirational to openly antagonistic.
content: During President Trump’s first term, his relationship with the N.F.L. was contentious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: ‘Dad, I Came Back Alive!’ Israeli Hostages Start to Give Glimpses of Ordeal.
description: Hostages freed before Saturday’s exchange have expressed relief and joy, while descriptions of the torment they endured are trickling out.
content: Doron Steinbrecher vowed that she would never wear pink again when she made her first public comments in a video after being freed from more than 15 months in Hamas captivity in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz
title: Why Federal Courts May Be the Last Bulwark Against Trump
description: With a compliant Congress and mostly quiet streets, the president’s opponents are turning to the judicial branch with a flurry of legal actions. But can the courts keep up?
content: More than 40 lawsuits filed in recent days by state attorneys general, unions and nonprofits seek to erect a bulwark in the federal courts against President Trump’s blitzkrieg of executive actions that have upended much of the federal government and challenged the Constitution’s system of checks and balances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman
title: Bird Flu Suspected in Deaths of Ducks and Wild Birds at N.Y.C. Zoos
description: Three ducks died of the disease at the Queens Zoo, while three more ducks and nine wild birds that died at the Bronx Zoo were being tested for the virus, according to the parks’ operator.
content: Three ducks at the Queens Zoo died because of bird flu, and as many as 12 more birds at the Bronx Zoo that died after possible exposure were being tested for the virus, according to the Wildlife Conservation Society, the nonprofit that operates the parks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: What to Know About Ecuador’s Presidential Election
description: As voters went to the polls on Sunday, violence, unemployment and the country’s ongoing energy crisis were top of mind.
content: Voters in Ecuador went to the polls on Sunday to decide whether Daniel Noboa, the center-right president, would receive another term after 15 months in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Bumiller
title: For Stunned Federal Workers, Sleeplessness, Anger and Tears
description: One thing lost in the Trump administration’s war on the federal bureaucracy is the collective voice of the employees. But some have begun to speak out.
content: One was fired by email at 12:47 a.m. Another wept with colleagues as security escorted her from the office. A third frantically tried to fill a prescription after she got a 24-hour notice that her health care was ending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Trump’s Shameful Campaign Against Transgender Americans
description: Trump’s attacks on trans people are on the wrong side of history and humanity.
content: Some of the most deplorable episodes in U.S. history involve the government wielding the power of the state against minority groups: Black people, Indigenous people and gay people, to name just a few. Though these campaigns might have received popular support at the time, history has consistently judged them as immoral, illegal and un-American.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Trump Says He Might Use U.S. Transit Agency to ‘Kill’ Congestion Pricing
description: In an interview with The New York Post, President Trump said that congestion pricing hurt New York City but indicated that he was still talking with Gov. Kathy Hochul.
content: President Trump said that he was considering using the federal Department of Transportation to “kill” congestion pricing, which he claimed was deterring people from coming into Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Angela Merkel Is Retired. But She’s Still on the Ballot.
description: If anything unites the parties in Germany’s election campaign, it is running away from the former chancellor, whose legacy voters have soured on.
content: A chorus of criticism greeted Friedrich Merz, the favorite to become Germany’s chancellor, last month when he broke a taboo against working with a hard-right party to pass legislation. But it was a lone voice of dissent that rocked the country’s political scene: Angela Merkel, the once-beloved former chancellor, who called Mr. Merz’s decision simply “wrong.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: Some Afrikaners Cheer as Trump Amplifies Claims of Persecution
description: An executive order from President Trump on Friday put the weight of U.S. influence behind a hotly disputed claim in South Africa that Afrikaners were the “victims of unjust racial discrimination.”
content: For decades, some members of the white Afrikaner minority have been trying to convince anyone and everyone who would listen that they are the true victims in post-apartheid South Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Minho Kim
title: Vance Says ‘Judges Aren’t Allowed to Control’ Trump’s ‘Legitimate Power’
description: The declaration by the vice president came as court orders have temporarily blocked parts of the Trump administration’s agenda.
content: Vice President JD Vance declared on Sunday that “judges aren’t allowed to control the executive’s legitimate power,” delivering a warning shot to the federal judiciary in the face of court rulings that have, for now, stymied aspects of President Trump’s agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall and Callaghan O'Hare
title: Can a Golden Retriever Win at Westminster? History Says No.
description: They are among the most popular dogs in the United States, but at the biggest dog show in the world, they are never (never!) best in show.
content: Who would not want to award a blue ribbon to Boujee the golden retriever, with her boundless enthusiasm and ineffable talent for maintaining her dignity while clamoring for attention? One swoosh of her magnificent tail and it’s easy to see why this blond bombshell is the top-ranked golden competing at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, with judging to begin on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: Can $400 Million Rescue New York’s Run-Down Capital City?
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has proposed to earmark $400 million to revitalize the capital of New York, where poverty rates are high and the downtown is moribund.
content: The blight that pervades downtown Albany is hard to miss. Buildings are boarded up just blocks from the New York State Capitol. Chain-link fencing and other barriers surround the crumbling Capitol staircase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Behind a Mass Shooting Trial in Texas, a Lawyer’s Own Grief
description: Lori Laird was defending a couple whose son shot 23 people at his school, while engaged in a desperate struggle with her own son’s mental illness. When are parents to blame?
content: One day a year ago in southeast Texas, Lori Laird got a text from a friend and fellow lawyer with an unusually urgent request for help: He had clients to offload. And fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: Trump’s Blueprint for Bending the Media Has Nixon Written All Over It
description: The president’s heavy-handed approach to traditional journalists has the hallmarks of an attempted crackdown 50 years ago.
content: Voters had delivered the president to the White House for a second term, disregarding news about arrests and indictments of former aides accused of breaking the law to help keep him in power. Now, the newly emboldened president and his top officials had a message for the reporters who covered it all so aggressively: It was payback time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Democrats Hint at Government Shutdown to Stop Trump’s Axing at Federal Agencies
description: Two Democratic senators from New Jersey, Cory Booker and Andy Kim, said Democrats should not vote for a spending package that would affirm President Trump’s agenda in gutting federal agencies.
content: Two Democratic senators said on Sunday that their party would not rule out forcing the federal government to shut down to stop President Trump’s legally questionable actions in dismantling federal agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Russell Vought Orders Consumer Protection Bureau’s Headquarters Closed for a Week
description: The order to shutter the agency’s headquarters follows another order issued Saturday by Mr. Vought, who also leads the Office of Management and Budget, telling agency employees to halt nearly all their work.
content: Employees at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau received an email on Sunday saying the bureau’s headquarters would be closed for the coming week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Populist Cure Is Worse Than the Elite Disease
description: The push-me-pull-you relationship between Trump and his movement has a long history.
content: Steve Bannon made me laugh out loud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Georgia Man Sentenced to 475 Years for Dogfighting
description: Vincent Lemark Burrell was found guilty last month of more than 100 counts of dogfighting and animal cruelty after dozens of dogs were found in poor condition at his home.
content: A Georgia man who the authorities said kept more than 100 dogs in cruel conditions at his home has been sentenced to 475 years in prison after being found guilty last month of dogfighting and cruelty to animals, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger and Christiana Botic
title: One Big Super Bowl Tailgate: Celebrities Embrace New Orleans.
description: Events around the city featured Travis Scott, Post Malone, Snoop Dogg and more, while Taylor Swift caused a stir everywhere she went.
content: On Friday night, two gigantic footballs each one made of more than 400,000 sparkly gold tiles hung in the humid air and rotated like disco balls over a stage in New Orleans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Had Decided I Wanted to Spend Some Time Outside After Work’
description: Just the right spot in Prospect Park, mesmerized by Manhattan and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Democrats Are in Disarray. Now What?
description: Readers differ about whom to blame for the party’s situation and how to fix it. Also: Asheville’s challenges; caring for mental health.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Seal the Deal
description: We’ve got a play date with Emily Rourke’s crossword.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Wright-Piersanti
title: Ready for the Super Bowl?
description: Here’s a guide to tonight’s game.
content: The Kansas City Chiefs meet the Philadelphia Eagles in New Orleans for Super Bowl LIX tonight, and it’s likely that more than 100 million people will tune in. For many, it will be the only football game they watch this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Pattee
title: Trading Hope for Reality Helps Me Parent Through the Climate Crisis
description: In the hospital, I learned the first lesson of parenting: You are not in control of what is going to happen, nor can you predict it.
content: When I gave birth to my first child, in 2019, it seemed like everything that could possibly go wrong went wrong. He came out white and limp, his head dangling off to the side. People swarmed into the hospital room, trying to suction his lungs so he could breathe. Hours later, my husband and I stood in the NICU, looking down at this newborn baby, hooked up to wires and tubes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green, Hurubie Meko and Alan Feuer
title: Trump to Revoke Security Clearances for Prosecutors and Biden Officials
description: Former Secretary of State Antony Blinken, Attorney General Letitia James of New York and the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin Bragg, were among those the president singled out.
content: President Trump will revoke the security clearances of several current law enforcement figures and former national security officials, White House officials confirmed on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moises Velasquez-Manoff, Anthony Rey Perez, Tally Abecassis, Krish Seenivasan, John Woo, Aaron Esposito, Catherine Anderson and Quinton Kamara
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Some Raw Truths About Raw Milk’
description: Despite the serious risks of drinking it, a growing movement — including the potential health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — claims it has benefits. Should we take them more seriously?
content: Thousands of years ago, after domesticating cows and other ruminants, humans did something remarkable: They began to consume the milk from these animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Buckley
title: The End of the Blurb. Thank God.
description: On the higher slopes of Mount Olympus, blurbs are a way by which the gods speak to each other in code, with the whole world watching.
content: Are you sitting down? In what the trade publication Publisher’s Weekly reported as a “stunning" or “tour-de-force” development, the publisher of Simon & Schuster’s flagship imprint has announced that it will no longer require authors to provide promotional blurbs for their books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: An Esteemed Biographer Puts Her Own Life in the Spotlight
description: The standout essays in Megan Marshall’s “After Lives” recall her troubled father and the fate of a high school classmate.
content: “All biography is autobiography,” Ralph Waldo Emerson said, but most biographers are marginal by definition: parasites or scavengers, “the shadow in the garden,” to quote a godfather of the genre, James Atlas, in turn quoting his thorniest subject, Saul Bellow. When they step out of the margins it’s often because something has gone wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,332
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Feb. 10, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Gyalo Thondup, Political Operator and Brother of the Dalai Lama, Dies at 97
description: Mr. Thondup’s influence in Tibet has been seen as second only to his younger brother, Tenzin Gyatso, the exiled head of Tibetan Buddhism, whom he spent decades trying to help return to their homeland.
content: Gyalo Thondup, the eldest brother of the Dalai Lama and a political operator in Tibet and the greater region, has died, the Dalai Lama’s office confirmed in a statement. He died on Sunday in Kalimpong in West Bengal, India, according to Tibetan media. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Ramaswamy’s Celebrity and Trump Ties Give Him a Jump in Ohio Governor’s Race
description: Vivek Ramaswamy’s short and rocky tenure in Washington isn’t turning off Republican voters in his home state.
content: On Monday morning, as Vivek Ramaswamy was soft-launching his campaign for governor of Ohio, Dan Merenoff sat at a coffee-shop counter in Delaware, a suburb of Columbus, weighing the prospect of Mr. Ramaswamy, a political celebrity but a governing novice, running the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: 36 Hours After Russell Vought Took Over Consumer Bureau, He Shut Its Operations
description: The agency had been one of Wall Street’s most feared regulators, with the power to issue rules on mortgages, credit cards, student loans and other areas affecting Americans’ financial lives.
content: The day before Linda Wetzel closed on her retirement home in Southport, N.C., in 2012 — a cozy place where she could open the windows at night and catch an ocean breeze — the bank making the loan surprised her with a fee she hadn’t expected. Ms. Wetzel scoured her mortgage paperwork and couldn’t find the charge disclosed anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Natan Odenheimer and Ephrat Livni
title: Israeli Troops Withdraw From Key Zone Bisecting Gaza
description: During the war with Hamas, troops patrolled the Netzarim Corridor, which splits Gaza, preventing evacuated Palestinians from returning north.
content: Israel’s military withdrew Sunday from a key corridor dividing the Gaza Strip, leaving nearly all of the territory’s north, as required by a tenuous cease-fire with Hamas ahead of any negotiations for a longer-lasting agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meytal Ofer
title: I Do Not Want Revenge for My Father’s Death
description: My father’s killer is being released to save hostages.
content: On a warm October night 12 years ago, my father, Yaya Ofer, was murdered by two Palestinian terrorists. They attacked him at home, at night, with axes, landing 41 blows on his body. His killing was planned. My father, who had retired as a colonel in the Israeli Army, had been the central figure in my childhood. As an adult, I loved hiking with him all over this country and meeting people from every background. In one evening all that was gone. The attackers were sentenced to life in prison. Now, as part of the cease-fire deal between Israel and Hamas, one of those men will walk free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Court Blocks U.S. From Sending 3 Venezuelan Migrants to Guantánamo
description: The men, who are detained in New Mexico, say they “fit the profile” of the type of migrants the Trump administration has started sending to the Navy base in Cuba.
content: A federal judge barred the U.S. government on Sunday from sending three detained Venezuelan men to the Navy base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, according to a lawyer for the migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Dillon
title: A French Widow Agonizes Over Her Husband’s Fatal Accident
description: In the 2022 Prix Goncourt-winning novel “Live Fast,” Brigitte Giraud pieces together the motorcycle crash that killed the narrator’s husband, while tearing her apart.
content: Some of the things we inevitably say to one another in real life are very hard to pull off in fiction. “Had I known then what I know now” is a creative-writing-class blunder that the French writer Brigitte Giraud has nonetheless made central to an autobiographical novel of great formal and emotional urgency. “Live Fast,” which won the Prix Goncourt in 2022, takes its title from a stray cliché by Lou Reed that the narrator finds in a book her husband, Claude, was reading back in 1999, when he was 41, right before he died in a motorcycle accident. Twenty years later, the narrator looks back and tries to piece events together — or, rather, tear them apart in a welter of regret, paranoia, blame and fantasy: all driven by an overbearing “if only.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Monday Briefing: The Last Guard Against Trump’s Orders?
description: Plus, a study in swearing.
content: More than 40 lawsuits have been filed in recent days by state attorneys general, unions and nonprofits seeking to erect a barrier against President Trump’s blitzkrieg of executive orders. Vice President JD Vance yesterday accused any judges who might block the president’s orders of acting illegally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger and Christiana Botic
title: At the Super Bowl Ladies Lounge, N.F.L. Wives Stick Together
description: A party hosted by the National Football Wives Association gave the partners of players, both active and retired, a chance to connect and unwind.
content: It was Saturday in a balmy New Orleans, and Jennifer Slay, the wife of Darius Slay Jr., a cornerback for the Philadelphia Eagles, was at a party in the French Quarter, hugging and greeting a crowd of women whose husbands also play professional football, some for the Kansas City Chiefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Sam Nujoma, Founding President of Namibia, Dies at 95
description: As the self-exiled leader of the South-West Africa People’s Organization, he directed a guerrilla army in a 24-year war for independence from South African rule.
content: Sam Nujoma, the founding president of an independent Namibia, who led a Soviet-backed guerrilla army in an uneven fight against the vastly superior forces of white-ruled South Africa in a victory that owed much to the dynamics of the Cold War, died on Saturday in Windhoek, Namibia’s capital. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker and Nataliya Vasilyeva
title: An American Teacher Went to Ukraine. Now He’s in a Russian Prison.
description: Stephen Hubbard was a wanderer. But when he moved to Ukraine, the war brought arrest, torture and imprisonment. He turns 73 this week.
content: Stephen James Hubbard left America behind decades ago, first for Japan, then Cyprus and finally Ukraine. He didn’t like the government — any government, really.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
title: Dozens of Maoist Guerrillas Killed in Central India, Officials Say
description: Rebels known as Naxalites have waged an insurgency that has ebbed and flowed over decades, but government operations have given them less space to maneuver.
content: Dozens of Maoist guerrillas were killed in central India by government forces on Sunday, one of the deadliest operations in recent years against leftist rebels who have waged an insurgency that has ebbed and flowed over several decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: When Clothing Is Also a Bullhorn
description: For some designers, sustainability, gender and inclusion are still in style.
content: “I started designing this before the election,” Joseph Altuzarra said on the Saturday of New York Fashion Week, gesturing at his collection. “And then, as things began to unfold, we started changing things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: 4 New Detective Novels Worth Investigating
description: Our critic on the month’s most notable releases.
content: A new Pentecost and Parker novel has arrived! A frabjous day in the world of crime fiction. Spotswood’s fifth installment in this beloved series, DEAD IN THE FRAME (Doubleday, 358 pp., $28), is particularly memorable. The great detective Lillian Pentecost has been arrested for the murder of the repulsive, crime-addicted philanthropist Jessup Quincannon, whose “eyes gleamed when he landed on the topic of murder” and “whose voice quivered with pleasure as he ran his fingers over a cutthroat razor that had been used to leave a woman bleeding out in the gutter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: 2 Million Baked Goods Are Recalled Over Listeria Risk
description: The recall, which was initiated on Jan. 7 and upgraded on Wednesday, includes several Dunkin’ products, federal safety officials said.
content: About two million baked goods, including some doughnuts and coffee rolls sold at Dunkin’, were recalled over concerns of potential contamination with the bacteria Listeria monocytogenes, federal safety regulators said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Early Crypto Traders Had Speedy Profit on Trump Coin as Others Suffered Losses
description: Some traders made tens of millions off a new cryptocurrency launched by President Trump and his sons. Many others lost out.
content: The curious trade came a little past 9 p.m. on Jan. 17 — a $1,096,109 bet less than two minutes after the soon-to-be president of the United States posted on his social media account that his family had issued a cryptocurrency called $Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Trump Will Impose Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum on Monday
description: The president said he planned sweeping tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports on Monday and would take other action to even out tariff rates with the rest of the world later this week.
content: President Trump on Sunday said that he would impose a 25 percent tariff on all foreign steel and aluminum imports into the United States as of Monday and would soon announce reciprocal tariffs on America’s trading partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 610
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Feb. 10, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Jalapeño-Corn Dip, a Super Bowl
description: Follow it up with ham and cheese sliders and frosted sugar cookies. Winners all.
content: Good morning. It’s Birds vs. Chiefs this evening and great swaths of the nation will be watching the game, taking in the hits and the ads, looking for Taylor Swift in the crowd, wondering what Kendrick Lamar will do at halftime, wondering if Kansas City can three-peat a National Championship against its rivals from Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Anora’ Wins Big at Producers and Directors Guild Awards
description: The film that takes those two major industry prizes almost always goes on to win the best-picture Oscar.
content: This tumultuous Oscar season has a certified front-runner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe, Joey K. Lee and Bea Malsky
title: Map: 7.6-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes the Caribbean
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe, Joey K. Lee and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking a Potential Tsunami in the Caribbean
description: Monitor warnings and predicted arrival times for the ocean wave.
content: Monitor warnings and predicted arrival times for the ocean wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Laura Bult, James Surdam and Ray Whitehouse
title: The Winners and Losers of Trump’s Memecoin
description: A small group of crypto insiders and other early investors in Trump’s meme coin made millions of dollars and inflated the price of the cryptocurrency. But many average investors who came late to the game have lost money. Eric Lipton, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains what happened.
content: A small group of crypto insiders and other early investors in Trump’s meme coin made millions of dollars and inflated the price of the cryptocurrency. But many average investors who came late to the game have lost money. Eric Lipton, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains what happened.
source.name: The New York Times
